slides.subheading: Our Amazing Ears — Sense of Hearing
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we get to learn all about our ears and how they help us hear. Our ears are super special, and they let us hear all sorts of wonderful things!

slides.setup_instructions: Print or draw a simple ear diagram. Prepare a clipboard for the sound walk.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our hearing adventure! We have a picture to show us how our ears work, a special book for writing, a pencil for drawing, a board to hold our paper, and a timer to count our listening time. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these things?

slides.text: 'Sound is invisible! It travels through the air as waves. Your ear catches those waves and sends messages to your brain.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it amazing? Our ears help us hear things that we can't even see! Sound travels through the air like invisible waves, and your ears are like little catcher's mitts for those waves. They catch the sounds and tell your brain what's happening!

slides.text: 'Cup your hands behind your ears like this. Does everything sound louder? Your hands are catching more sound waves!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try something fun! Can you cup your hands around your ears like this? Do things sound a little bit louder now? Your hands are helping your ears catch even more of those invisible sound waves, like a bigger catcher's mitt!

slides.text: 'Now let's go on a SOUND WALK. For 3 minutes, be perfectly quiet and listen. Write down every single sound you hear.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's go on a special listening adventure, a "sound walk"! We need to be super quiet for just three minutes and listen very, very carefully. Let's see how many different sounds we can hear and remember them all!

slides.text: 'Let's look at your list. Can we sort these sounds? Natural sounds like birds... and human-made sounds like cars.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great listening! Now, let's look at all the sounds we heard. We can sort them into two groups: sounds that happen all by themselves in nature, like birds singing, and sounds that people make, like a car driving by.

slides.prompt: In your science journal, make a two-column chart: Natural Sounds and Human-Made Sounds. Sort your sound walk list. Draw a picture of your favorite sound.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our special chart in your science book! We'll draw two boxes, one for nature sounds and one for sounds people make, and put all the sounds we heard into the right boxes. Which sound was your favorite to listen to?

slides.text: 'You heard so many sounds! Your ears are always working, even when you are asleep. Hearing keeps us safe and connected to the world.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify at least 8 sounds during the sound walk and correctly classify them as natural or human-made?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a fantastic job listening today! Your ears are always working, helping you hear the world around you and keeping you safe. It's so cool that you heard so many sounds and knew if they were from nature or from people!

parent_notes: The sound walk is one of the most powerful Montessori science activities because it requires silence — a skill your child has been developing since their first days of Montessori work. In silence, children notice sounds they normally filter out: the hum of the refrigerator, distant traffic, wind in trees, their own breathing. This heightened awareness is both scientific observation and mindfulness practice. The classification activity (natural vs. human-made) introduces a key scientific skill: sorting data into categories. If your child is interested, extend by discussing animal hearing: 'Dogs can hear sounds that are too high for our ears!'
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Music Exploration — Making Sound Instruments
description: The child creates simple musical instruments from household materials and experiments with pitch, volume, and rhythm. This connects the hearing science theme with creative expression.
instructions:
1. 'We learned about hearing today. Now let's MAKE sounds with instruments we create ourselves!'
2. Present materials for 2-3 instruments:
   - Shaker: small container filled with rice or beans
   - Drum: overturned pot or box with a wooden spoon
   - Guitar: rubber bands stretched over an open box
3. Make each instrument together.
4. Experiment: 'How do you make it louder? Softer? Higher? Lower?'
5. Play a simple rhythm pattern. The child echoes it.
6. Free play: the child creates their own song or rhythm.
materials_needed: Open box and rubber bands (for guitar)

slides.heading: Making Music
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make some super fun music today by building our very own instruments, just like real musicians! It's going to be so exciting to see what we can create together.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all materials on a large work surface. Have examples of each instrument ready to show.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's gather our special building stuff! We have little containers for shaking, some yummy-sounding rice or beans, a big pot and a spoon for drumming, and a box with stretchy rubber bands that will be like a guitar. Ask your grown-up to help you find these things so we can start making music!

slides.text: 'Musicians make sounds with instruments. Today we are going to BUILD our own instruments and explore how sound works!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to be like amazing builders and musicians today! We learned that sounds are all around us, and now we get to make our *own* sounds with instruments we build ourselves. Isn't that neat?

slides.text: 'First, a shaker! Fill this container with rice. Close the lid tight. Shake it! Now try beans — does it sound different?'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's make a shaker! We’ll put some rice inside this container and close it up tight. When we shake it, it makes a fun sound! Now, let's try putting beans inside instead – listen, does it sound different?

slides.text: 'Next, a drum! Turn this pot upside down and tap with the spoon. Tap softly... now loudly! You control the volume.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's make a drum! We'll turn this pot upside down, and then we get to tap it with our wooden spoon. Listen to the sound when we tap softly, and then try tapping it much louder – you're in charge of how loud it is!

slides.text: 'Last, a stringed instrument. Stretch rubber bands over this box. Pluck them! A tight band makes a higher sound, a loose band makes a lower sound.'
slides.mascot_explanation: For our last instrument, we'll make a stringed one! We'll stretch these rubber bands over the box. When you gently pull and let go of a rubber band, it makes a musical sound. A tighter band makes a higher sound, and a looser one makes a lower sound.

slides.prompt: Play your instruments! Can you make a loud sound and a soft sound? A high sound and a low sound? Create a short song using all three instruments.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to play our awesome instruments! Can you make your shaker sound loud and then soft? How about your drum – can you make a high sound and then a low sound? Let’s try playing a little song together with all our new instruments!

slides.text: 'You are a musician AND a scientist! You discovered that sound changes when you change how you play — louder, softer, higher, lower.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate volume control (loud/soft) and identify pitch differences (high/low) using their homemade instruments?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a fantastic job! You are a super musician and a clever scientist because you learned how to make sounds loud and soft, and even high and low with the instruments you made! The coolest part was probably making your own special music, right?

parent_notes: Making instruments from everyday objects is deeply Montessori — it shows the child that learning materials are everywhere, not just in purchased kits. The scientific concepts here are real: pitch is determined by the frequency of vibration (tight rubber bands vibrate faster = higher pitch), and volume is determined by the force applied. You do not need to explain this in technical terms, but the child's hands-on discovery lays the groundwork. Let the child experiment freely after the guided portion. Some children will spend a long time adjusting rubber band tension to get different notes. This curiosity-driven exploration is exactly what Montessori education cultivates.
household_substitutes: Pots, pans, wooden spoons for rhythm
preparation_steps: Gather sound-making objects. Choose a space where noise is okay.
control_of_error: Can the child repeat a rhythm pattern? Can they keep a steady beat?
extension_ideas: Create a simple song together
Clap rhythm patterns for each other to copy
Listen to different genres and compare

title: Independent Work Cycle — Extended Period with Journal Reflection
description: The child completes an extended independent work period choosing four works, then writes a brief journal reflection about their experience. This prepares them for the longer work cycles of elementary.
instructions:
1. 'Today is an extended work period. You will choose FOUR works and take your time with each one.'
2. Set a gentle timer for 40 minutes.
3. The child works independently, choosing, completing, and returning works.
4. After the work period, provide a journal page: 'Draw or write about your favorite work today. What did you learn? What was easy? What was hard?'
5. The child completes the journal entry.
6. Share and discuss the journal entry together.
materials_needed: Journal or lined paper with drawing space

slides.heading: Extended Work Cycle
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! Today we're going to do something super special called an "Extended Work Cycle." It means we get to play and learn for a longer time, and then we get to draw about it!

slides.setup_instructions: Refresh the shelves if needed. Prepare a journal page with: My Favorite Work Today (drawing space) and What I Learned (lined space).
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our big work day! We have our work shelves with all our fun activities, a special mat to keep our work tidy, a paper to draw on, pencils for coloring, and a timer to tell us when it's time to switch.

slides.text: 'Today is a big work day! You will choose FOUR works — one more than usual. This is like what older students do in elementary school.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is a super important day because we get to choose FOUR special activities to do all by ourselves! That's more than usual, just like the big kids in elementary school do.

slides.text: 'Take your time. There is no rush. Focus on each work completely before moving to the next.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We are going to take our time and really focus on each activity, just like a super detective looking for clues. There's no need to hurry, we can enjoy every single bit of our learning time.

slides.text: 'When the timer chimes, finish your current work and put it away. Then it is time for your journal reflection.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When you hear the little chime sound from our timer, it means it's time to finish up what you're doing and put it away nicely. Then, we get to do something fun and creative with our journal!

slides.prompt: Complete four works independently. Then draw and write about your favorite work in your journal: What was it? What did you learn? What was easy or hard?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the super fun part! You get to pick four activities and do them all by yourself for a good long time, and then you get to draw a picture and write about your very favorite one in your journal. What did you learn? Was it tricky or easy?

slides.text: 'You worked independently for a long time today! Your journal entry shows your thinking. This is what real learners do — work, reflect, and grow.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sustain independent work for 40 minutes across four works and produce a meaningful journal reflection?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job working all by yourself for a long time today! Your drawing and writing in your journal show how much you learned and thought about your work. That's what super learners do!

parent_notes: This extended work period prepares your child for elementary, where work cycles typically last 2-3 hours. The journal reflection is a powerful addition — it develops metacognition (thinking about thinking) and writing skills simultaneously. Do not worry about the quality of the journal entry at first. Some children will draw detailed pictures with one sentence; others will write several sentences with a quick sketch. Both are valid expressions of reflection. Over time, these journal entries become a beautiful record of your child's growth and interests. Save them — they are precious documentation of your child's Montessori journey.

title: Reading Comprehension — Retelling with Sequence
description: The child reads a short story and retells it in sequence using the words first, then, next, and finally. This develops narrative comprehension and oral language skills essential for writing.
instructions:
1. Present sequence words on cards: FIRST, THEN, NEXT, FINALLY.
2. 'When we retell a story, we use these words to keep events in order.'
3. Read a short story together (or the child reads independently).
4. 'Now retell the story using these words. FIRST, what happened?'
5. Guide the child through the retelling, placing each sequence card as they talk.
6. The child writes or draws 4 panels showing the story sequence.
7. Read the retelling aloud.
materials_needed: Short story at child's reading level
Sequence word cards (First, Then, Next, Finally)

slides.heading: Story Retelling
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this fun title! It says "Story Retelling" and has some special words: "First, Then, Next, Finally." We're going to learn how to tell stories in the right order, like a super storyteller!

slides.setup_instructions: Print sequence word cards large enough to place on the table. Prepare a paper folded or divided into 4 boxes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to get our special tools ready for our story adventure! We have a story to read, some word cards with "First," "Then," "Next," and "Finally" on them, and paper with four boxes for drawing our story. You can ask a grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'Today we will retell a story in ORDER. These words help us: FIRST, THEN, NEXT, FINALLY.' Show each card.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, my friend, let's look at these important words. We have "FIRST," "THEN," "NEXT," and "FINALLY." These words are like magic helpers that tell us what happened at the start, in the middle, and at the end of a story. They help us remember everything in the right order!

slides.text: 'Read this story carefully. When you finish, you will tell it back to me using our sequence words.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to read our story! Read it super carefully, like you're looking for hidden treasures. When you're done, we'll use our special word cards to tell the story back, just like we're putting the puzzle pieces together.

slides.text: 'FIRST, what happened at the beginning? Place the FIRST card and tell me.' Continue with THEN, NEXT, FINALLY.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the magic really happens! We'll start with "FIRST" and tell me what happened at the very beginning of the story. Then we'll use "THEN" for the next part, "NEXT" for what came after that, and "FINALLY" for how the story ended. We're going to be amazing storytellers!

slides.prompt: Draw the four parts of the story in order on your story strip. Write a sentence under each picture using: First..., Then..., Next..., Finally...
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the artist and writer! In each box, draw a picture of what happened in the story. After you draw, write "First..." under the first picture, "Then..." under the second, "Next..." under the third, and "Finally..." under the last one. You've got this!

slides.text: 'You retold the whole story in order! These sequence words help organize your thoughts — you can use them when you write your own stories too.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell a story in correct sequence using at least 3 of the 4 sequence words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You told the whole story using "First," "Then," "Next," and "Finally" – that's amazing! These special words help us remember things in order, and you can use them to tell your own stories too. You are such a fantastic storyteller!

parent_notes: Retelling in sequence is a critical comprehension skill and a direct precursor to writing. When children learn to organize events using transition words, they are building the narrative structure they need for their own compositions. The four-panel format provides visual scaffolding — each box represents one part of the story. If your child can retell orally but struggles to write, let them draw first and add words after. The sequence words (first, then, next, finally) will become part of their writing vocabulary. You can practice this at any time: 'Tell me about your day using first, then, next, finally.'
household_substitutes: Short story at child's reading level
Sequence word cards (First, Then, Next, Finally)

control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?

Let the child show a family member what they learned

title: Subtraction — Fact Families
description: The child discovers that addition and subtraction are related by exploring fact families. Using concrete materials, they see that 3 + 5 = 8, 5 + 3 = 8, 8 - 3 = 5, and 8 - 5 = 3 are all part of the same number family.
instructions:
1. Present 8 counters. Separate them into groups of 3 and 5.
2. '3 and 5 make 8. Write it: 3 + 5 = 8.'
3. 'Turn it around: 5 and 3 also make 8. Write: 5 + 3 = 8.'
4. 'Now start with 8 and take away 3. What is left? 5! Write: 8 - 3 = 5.'
5. 'Start with 8 and take away 5. What is left? 3! Write: 8 - 5 = 3.'
6. 'These four equations are a FACT FAMILY — they all use the same three numbers!'
7. The child creates 2-3 more fact families with different numbers.

slides.heading: Fact Families
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Fact Families," and it means that adding numbers and taking numbers away are like brothers and sisters in a family. They work together in a super special way!

slides.setup_instructions: Place counters on the mat. Have paper ready for writing equations.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some fun things to play with today! We have these little colorful circles called counters, and we'll use them to help us count. We also have paper and a pencil to write down our number stories, and a special mat to keep everything tidy.

slides.text: 'Did you know that addition and subtraction are related — like a family? Let me show you!' Place 8 counters on the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get started with our number family! See these 8 little counters? We're going to use them to learn how numbers are friends with each other.

slides.text: Separate into 3 and 5. '3 plus 5 equals 8. And 5 plus 3 equals 8. Two addition facts!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put some of our counters together and some apart. See how we have 3 here and 5 there? When we put them together, they make 8! And guess what? If we put the 5 first and then the 3, they still make 8! So cool!

slides.text: 'Now watch: 8 minus 3 equals 5. And 8 minus 5 equals 3. Two subtraction facts! All four use the numbers 3, 5, and 8.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try taking some away. If we have our 8 counters and we take away 3, how many are left? Yep, 5! And if we start with 8 and take away 5, we have 3 left! All these number stories use the same three numbers: 3, 5, and 8.

slides.text: 'This is called a FACT FAMILY. If you know one fact, you can figure out the other three!'
slides.mascot_explanation: These special number stories are called a "Fact Family"! It's like they all live in the same house because they use the same three numbers. Knowing one math fact helps us know all the others in its family!

slides.prompt: Create fact families for: 4, 6, and 10. Then 2, 7, and 9. Write all four equations for each family. Use counters to check.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to make some fact families! Let's use the counters to help us. We'll figure out the number family for 4, 6, and 10, and then another one for 2, 7, and 9. You can write down all the adding and taking away stories for each one.

slides.text: 'Fact families show that addition and subtraction are connected! When you know 6 + 4 = 10, you automatically know 10 - 4 = 6.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child generate all four equations in a fact family given three related numbers?
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray! We learned that adding and subtracting are like a big happy family! When you know that 6 plus 4 makes 10, you also know that if you have 10 and take away 4, you get 6! You're so good at finding these number families!

parent_notes: Fact families are one of the most important concepts in early mathematics because they reveal the inverse relationship between addition and subtraction. When a child truly understands this, they effectively halve the number of facts they need to memorize — knowing 3 + 5 = 8 gives them three more facts for free. The concrete materials make this relationship visible: the same 8 counters can be grouped as 3 and 5 or regrouped as 5 and 3, and taking away either group always leaves the other. This is NOT just a worksheet exercise — the hands-on discovery with objects builds genuine understanding that paper-only practice cannot achieve.

title: Community Helpers — The Scientist in the Field
description: Exploring how scientists work in the field — biologists in nature, geologists studying rocks, marine biologists in the ocean — and conducting a mini field study.
instructions:
1. 'All week we have been doing science experiments. Did you know that some people do science as their JOB? They are called scientists!'
2. Discuss different types of scientists: biologists study living things, astronomers study stars, marine biologists study the ocean.
3. 'What did scientists use to discover everything in your science books? Their senses! And also special tools.'
4. Present scientist tools: magnifying glass, ruler, scale, thermometer.
5. The child draws a picture of themselves as a scientist with their tools.
6. 'What would YOU like to study as a scientist?'
materials_needed: Pictures of different types of scientists
Scientist tools: magnifying glass, ruler, simple scale, thermometer
Lab coat or white shirt (optional, for dramatic play)

slides.subheading: Community Helpers — The Scientist in the Field
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this big title! It says "Community Helpers," and that means people who help us all in our neighborhood. Today, we're going to learn about a special kind of helper: a scientist who works outside!

slides.setup_instructions: Display pictures of different scientists at work. Arrange tools on a tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our science adventure! We have pictures of scientists working, and these special tools: a magnifying glass to see tiny things, a ruler to measure, a scale to weigh, and a thermometer to feel how hot or cold it is. We'll also need paper and crayons for drawing, so let's ask a grown-up to help us find them all!

slides.text: 'This week you have been a scientist! You observed, experimented, and recorded your findings. Some people do this every day as their job.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You've been doing such amazing science this week, playing and learning! Did you know some people do science as their whole job? They are called scientists, and they get to discover new things all the time!

slides.text: 'There are many kinds of scientists: biologists study plants and animals, chemists study substances, astronomers study space.'
slides.mascot_explanation: There are so many kinds of scientists! Some scientists, called biologists, love looking at plants and animals, and others, called astronomers, look way up at the stars in the sky! Isn't that neat?

slides.text: 'Scientists use tools to help their senses: a magnifying glass helps them SEE small things, a thermometer helps them FEEL temperature as a number.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Scientists use special tools to help them learn about the world. A magnifying glass helps them see super tiny things up close, like a little bug's legs, and a thermometer tells them if it's hot or cold, like when we check the weather!

slides.prompt: Draw yourself as a scientist! What are you studying? What tools are you using? Write a sentence: 'I am a ___ scientist. I study ___.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a scientist! Let's draw a picture of YOU as a scientist, using some of those cool tools. What do you want to study, like animals or stars? Then, we can write a sentence about it together!

slides.text: 'You already think like a scientist — you observe, ask questions, and try experiments. The world needs curious people like you!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 2 types of scientists and describe what scientists do (observe, experiment, discover)?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a super scientist! You are so good at looking closely, asking questions, and trying new things, just like all the helpers we talked about. The world needs curious friends like you to keep discovering!

parent_notes: Connecting the week's science work to real careers gives purpose and context to the child's learning. In Montessori education, community helpers are not just about jobs — they are about how individuals contribute to the greater good. Scientists improve medicine, protect the environment, and expand human knowledge. When the child draws themselves as a scientist, they are building identity: 'I can be a scientist.' This is especially important for children from underrepresented groups in STEM. Avoid gendered stereotypes — show diverse scientists. If your child is passionate about a particular area of science, research that type of scientist together.

title: Read-Aloud: All the Water in the World by George Ella Lyon
description: Reading 'All the Water in the World' by George Ella Lyon, a lyrical nonfiction picture book tracing the water cycle from rain to rivers to oceans and back again.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'Where does water come from? Where does it go?'
2. Read aloud — the text is poetic and rhythmic, like water itself.
3. Follow the water cycle: rain, puddles, streams, rivers, ocean, evaporation, clouds, rain again.
4. Discuss: 'The same water has been here since dinosaurs! How is that possible?'
5. Talk about taking care of water: 'Why is it important?'
6. Connect to your own observations of rain, puddles, and streams.
materials_needed: All the Water in the World by George Ella Lyon
Optional: a glass of water to observe

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: All the Water in the World by George Ella Lyon
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, friend! We're going to read a special book today called "All the Water in the World." It's going to be a fun adventure all about water!

items: All the Water in the World book
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. A glass of water makes a wonderful prop.
slides.mascot_explanation: To help us with our story, we need our book, "All the Water in the World." If you want, you can also have a little glass of water nearby to see how it moves!

slides.text: Cover: 'This book is about all the water in the world. Where do you think water comes from?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at the front of our book. It has a picture and asks a big question: "Where does water come from?" What do you think? Does it come from the sky, or maybe from a faucet?

slides.text: Read with flowing rhythm — the text moves like water. Katherine Tillotson's illustrations are luminous.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to read our book! Listen to how the words sound, they move like water flowing, and look at the pretty pictures. We'll follow the water as it goes on its journey.

slides.text: Discuss: 'Where does rain go? How does it get back up to the clouds? Is the water in your glass really, really old?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to talk about where the rain goes after it falls. Does it stay in a puddle, or does it flow to bigger places like rivers and the ocean? And guess what? The water might be super, super old!

slides.prompt: Draw the water cycle: rain falling, going into a puddle, flowing to a river, reaching the ocean, evaporating up to clouds, and raining again!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to make a picture! Let's draw how the water goes from the clouds, down to the ground, into a river, and then back up to the clouds again. It's like a big circle!

slides.text: 'All the water in the world goes round and round. The water you drink today might have been a dinosaur's puddle!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe at least three steps of the water cycle?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! We learned that water goes round and round, and the water we have today has been here for a very, very long time, maybe even since the dinosaurs were little! You can tell me three things the water does on its trip.

parent_notes: This poetic nonfiction book makes the water cycle accessible and magical for young children. It connects to Montessori's science curriculum and the child's natural curiosity about weather and nature. The conservation message is gentle but important. Consider doing a water cycle observation — leave a bowl of water in the sun and watch evaporation happen.
